instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spin, no vcore
threads.message:
Working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no signs of water damage. Costumer says he turned it of and the next day it wont start again.

Wont start at all without battery
With battery I get fan spin but no vcore present.

14.7 ohm to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> but 0V
L7310 get 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0.04v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spin, no vcore
threads.message:
replaced <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and starting up but with 3 beeps
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> now 1.35v and vcore are there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spin, no vcore
threads.message:
Looks like RAM issue.
Be aware, you should change all FDMF6808 chips; with new FDMF6708.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spin, no vcore
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spin, no vcore
threads.message: To avoid warranty returns. They cause random crashing/the issues you are seeing. Also going to have to reflow RAM to see if beeps go away.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spin, no vcore
threads.message: Ok, thank you did not know that. But first of all I have to fix ram issue.
